an4.160:3.1: 160 The Training of a Holy One
an4.160:4.1: “Mendicants, a Holy One or a Holy One’s training remain in the world for the welfare and happiness of many people, out of compassion for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.
an4.160:5.1: And who is a Holy One?
an4.160:5.2: It’s when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme trainer of people, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.
an4.160:6.1: And what is the training of a Holy One?
an4.160:6.2: He teaches Dharma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
an4.160:6.3: This is the training of a Holy One.
an4.160:6.4: This is how a Holy One or a Holy One’s training remain in the world for the welfare and happiness of many people, out of compassion for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.
an4.160:7.1: These four things lead to the decline and disappearance of the true teaching.
an4.160:7.3: Firstly, the mendicants memorize discourses that they learned incorrectly, with misplaced words and phrases.
an4.160:7.4: When the words and phrases are misplaced, the meaning is misinterpreted.
an4.160:7.5: This is the first thing that leads to the decline and disappearance of the true teaching.
an4.160:8.1: Furthermore, the mendicants are hard to correct, having qualities that make them hard to correct. They’re impatient, and don’t take instruction respectfully.
an4.160:8.2: This is the second thing that leads to the decline and disappearance of the true teaching.
an4.160:9.1: Furthermore, the mendicants who are very learned—knowledgeable in the scriptures, who have memorized the teachings, the Vinaya, and the outlines—don’t carefully make others recite the discourses.
an4.160:9.2: When they pass away, the discourses are cut off at the root, with no-one to preserve them.
an4.160:9.3: This is the third thing that leads to the decline and disappearance of the true teaching.
an4.160:10.1: Furthermore, the senior mendicants are indulgent and slack, leaders in backsliding, neglecting seclusion, not rousing energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.
an4.160:10.2: Those who come after them follow their example.
an4.160:10.3: They too become indulgent and slack, leaders in backsliding, neglecting seclusion, not rousing energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.
an4.160:10.4: This is the fourth thing that leads to the decline and disappearance of the true teaching.
an4.160:10.5: These are four things that lead to the decline and disappearance of the true teaching.
an4.160:11.1: These four things lead to the continuation, persistence, and enduring of the true teaching.
an4.160:11.3: Firstly, the mendicants memorize discourses that have been learned correctly, with well placed words and phrases.
an4.160:11.4: When the words and phrases are well placed, the meaning is interpreted correctly.
an4.160:11.5: This is the first thing that leads to the continuation, persistence, and enduring of the true teaching.
an4.160:12.1: Furthermore, the mendicants are easy to correct, having qualities that make them easy to correct. They’re patient, and take instruction respectfully.
an4.160:12.2: This is the second thing that leads to the continuation, persistence, and enduring of the true teaching.
an4.160:13.1: Furthermore, the mendicants who are very learned—knowledgeable in the scriptures, who have memorized the teachings, the Vinaya, and the outlines—carefully make others recite the discourses.
an4.160:13.2: When they pass away, the discourses aren’t cut off at the root, and they have someone to preserve them.
an4.160:13.3: This is the third thing that leads to the continuation, persistence, and enduring of the true teaching.
an4.160:14.1: They too become indulgent and slack, leaders in backsliding, neglecting seclusion, not rousing energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.
an4.160:14.2: Those who come after them follow their example.
an4.160:14.3: They too aren’t indulgent or slack …
an4.160:14.4: This is the fourth thing that leads to the continuation, persistence, and enduring of the true teaching.
an4.160:14.5: These are four things that lead to the continuation, persistence, and enduring of the true teaching.”
